word.entryDescription: to become more developed or to make something, usually a plant, more developed
word.entryExample: Farmers grow cacao in Africa and South America.

word.entryDescription: to develop from a child into an adult
word.entryExample: Harry, what do you think you'll be when you grow up?

word.entryDescription: a person, company or place that grows plants or crops
word.entryExample: Columbia and Bolivia are major cocoa growers.

word.entryDescription: an increase in the number or size of something
word.entryExample: Britain has been observing a steady growth in the number of immigrants over the last years.

word.entryDescription: an insect in the stage when it has just come out of its egg
word.entryExample: On the south Pacific island of New Caledonia, the clever crows there make tools to get grubs to eat.

word.entryDescription: very tiring and difficult
word.entryExample: And then it's a gruelling four-day journey by camel across the desert.

word.entryDescription: to watch someone or something for the purpose of protection or to prevent escape
word.entryExample: It was guarded by police officers all day and night.

word.entryDescription: a person who is staying at a hotel
word.entryExample: The guests often have lots of requests.

word.entryDescription: a small hotel usually run by private people
word.entryExample: You can find places to stay, like hotels and guest houses in and around the city centre.

word.entryDescription: a book which gives you useful information, especially for people visiting a place
word.entryExample: It's useful to have a guidebook when you're travelling.

word.entryDescription: being found to have done something wrong
word.entryExample: He was found guilty of the crime.

word.entryDescription: a musical instrument with strings, a wide body and a long neck, which you play with your fingers
word.entryExample: Alex got a new guitar for his birthday.

word.entryDescription: a room in which you do physical exercise
word.entryExample: I go to the gym three times a week.

word.entryDescription: something that you do again and again, often without thinking about it
word.entryExample: Computers will use information about our habits and interests to help us find holidays.

word.entryDescription: the natural environment of a particular plant or animal
word.entryExample: The main habitat of the elephant seal is the sea.

word.entryDescription: small hard balls of ice that fall from the sky
word.entryExample: Natural extremes of climate, such as hail, hurricanes, tornadoes, droughts and floods, have been present throughout human history.

word.entryDescription: your hair grows on the top of your head and keeps it warm
word.entryExample: He has short brown hair.

word.entryDescription: somebody whose job is to cut and style hair
word.entryExample: To cut your hair while you're here, visit one of the many hairdressers across the city.

word.entryDescription: the profession of a hairdresser
word.entryExample: Perhaps I should go into hairdressing?

word.entryDescription: a very sharp bend in a road
word.entryExample: I was looking forward to arriving, although a little nervous at the idea of having to take responsibility for ourselves again after almost 72 hours of gazing passively at hairpin bends, desert haze and cliff-hugging roads.

word.entryDescription: 30 minutes after the hour
word.entryExample: I finish school at half past three.

word.entryDescription: with breakfast and one more meal - either dinner or lunch
word.entryExample: This hotel offers only half-board accommodation and I'm looking for full board.

word.entryDescription: at half the regular price
word.entryExample: I managed to buy this coat half-price on the winter sale.

word.entryDescription: referring to a short break between the two equal periods that some sports matches are divided into
word.entryExample: I think they must've had too much pizza to eat in the half-time break.

word.entryDescription: a building or large room for public events such as meetings, dances, meals, concerts, etc.
word.entryExample: I could book the hall and we could choose some great music to dance to.

word.entryDescription: meat from a pig's leg which has been preserved or processed
word.entryExample: I've got ham sandwiches for lunch.

word.entryDescription: to hit something with a hammer, or to make a series of short loud sounds by hitting a hard object against a hard surface
word.entryExample: The fence posts need to be hammered deep into the ground.

word.entryDescription: an animal like a large mouse with a short tail, often kept as a pet
word.entryExample: We have a pet hamster.

word.entryDescription: the part of the body at the end of your arm that you use to pick up or touch things
word.entryExample: Mum holds my hand when we cross the road.

word.entryDescription: to give something, e.g. homework, to a person in authority
word.entryExample: Please hand in your exam papers at 12 o'clock.

word.entryDescription: to give a particular thing to a number of people
word.entryExample: The children are just waiting for me to hand out their homework.

word.entryDescription: small enough to hold in your hand
word.entryExample: I think hand-held devices are the future and the bulky PCs are already old-fashioned.

word.entryDescription: a small bag that women often carry
word.entryExample: Is that red handbag yours?

word.entryDescription: a worksheet, a piece of paper given to everyone in a group, especially students
word.entryExample: Are we supposed to complete this handout now or at home?

word.entryDescription: the way that someone writes using a pen or pencil
word.entryExample: My handwriting has become hard to read since I started using keyboard to write.

word.entryDescription: a large frame covered with cloth that you hold on to and fly through the air without an engine
word.entryExample: Look at this hang glider over the Black Forest.

word.entryDescription: to spend a lot of time somewhere or with somebody
word.entryExample: I often hang out with friends but sometimes I stay at home and read or watch TV.

word.entryDescription: to attach something, or to be attached, at the top so that the lower part is free or loose
word.entryExample: Could you please hang my coat up?

word.entryDescription: to take place or occur
word.entryExample: A funny thing happened at school today.

word.entryDescription: feeling joy or pleasure
word.entryExample: Charlie is such a happy child.

word.entryDescription: solid; not easy to break
word.entryExample: Our hands and fingers help us feel if something is hot, warm or cold, wet or dry, soft or hard and if it hurts us.

word.entryDescription: the part of a computer that stores data and programs
word.entryExample: There isn't much spare storage space on my computer's hard drive.

word.entryDescription: doing a lot of work, or willing to work with a lot of effort
word.entryExample: To succeed, she needs to be much more hard-working.

word.entryDescription: the comparative form of 'hard' – firm and not easy to break or difficult
word.entryExample: This exercise is harder than I thought.

word.entryDescription: very little
word.entryExample: Nowadays we eat hardly any fresh, locally-produced food.

word.entryDescription: all technological equipment, but particularly the physical parts of a computer system
word.entryExample: I love using new devices and playing with hardware.

word.entryDescription: to hurt or damage
word.entryExample: We are hoping to design a kitchen knife which can never harm the user.

word.entryDescription: a feeling you have when you are happy and at peace with yourself and your surroundings
word.entryExample: The key to inner peace and harmony, some say is to learn how to focus.

word.entryDescription: to control and use something for a specific purpose
word.entryExample: Windmills have made it possible to harness the wind's energy on a smaller scale for hundreds of years.

word.entryDescription: the symbol ( # ), especially one on a telephone
word.entryExample: The recorded voice told me to press the hash key to connect with the office.
